misconceptions.name: Implemented average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program is written to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones, so the implemented algorithm does not correspond to the problem specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: I think the task is to read v0, v1, and t as doubles and compute the average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t, and that this solves the required problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, check which of them are even using n % 2 == 0, accumulate the sum of those even numbers, and then print that sum. No physics/acceleration calculation is required.
symptoms: The prompt asks for "v0, v1, and t" instead of 5 integers.
The program reads three double values rather than 5 integers.
The main printed result is "The average acceleration is ..." using the formula (v1 - v0) / t.
There is no code that sums multiple inputs or prints "Sum of even numbers".
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely copied a template/example for an average-acceleration problem and did not adapt the algorithm to the new specification, indicating difficulty in mapping problem requirements to an appropriate algorithm.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Before coding, restate the problem in your own words and write down the steps the program must take (read 5 integers, loop over them, check even, add to sum, print result). Then implement those steps one by one instead of reusing unrelated example code.
related_concepts: Tracing problem statement to input/output behavior
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All input prompts, variable names, and the final output clearly implement a different known textbook example (average acceleration) and never attempt to perform the requested sum of even numbers.

evidence.note: Prompt, variable names, and formula all correspond to an average-acceleration calculation, not reading 5 integers and summing the even ones.

misconceptions.name: Assuming indentation controls if-statement body without braces
misconceptions.description: The student writes an if statement with two indented lines below it but omits braces, which in Java means only the first statement is actually controlled by the if. This shows a misunderstanding of how blocks are formed in Java.
misconceptions.student_belief: If I indent multiple lines under an if condition, all of those indented lines will run only when the condition is true, even if I don’t use braces.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, an if without braces controls exactly one statement: the very next one. To execute multiple statements conditionally, you must enclose them in { } so they form a single block associated with the if.
symptoms: sum += num; is guarded by the if, but count++; will execute regardless of whether num is even.
The visual indentation suggests both statements are conditional, but the actual control flow is different.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely transferring expectations from pseudocode or languages/tutorials that stress indentation visually, without a solid grasp of Java’s precise rule that only the next statement is part of the if when braces are omitted.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always use braces for multi-line if bodies, even when they are not strictly required: if (condition) { ... }. Then step through an example where num is odd and see that count should not increase if the number is not even.
related_concepts: If statements and blocks in Java
Use of braces to define statement groups
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The classic pattern of omitting braces while indenting two lines strongly indicates the intent that both be conditional, a common beginner misunderstanding.

evidence.note: Because there are no braces, only sum += num; is inside the if; count++; always executes, contradicting the implied structure given by indentation.

misconceptions.name: Not using a loop to handle multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The code declares sum, count, and num, but only ever checks a single hard-coded value (num = 4) and never uses a loop to read or process 5 integers as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can handle this task by working with a single variable (like num = 4) and an if-statement, without needing a loop to iterate over all 5 values from the user.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To process 5 separate inputs, you need to either use a loop that repeats the read-and-check steps 5 times or otherwise ensure you read and process each of the 5 integers. A single hard-coded value is not sufficient.
symptoms: Only one integer variable num is defined and checked.
There is no for, while, or repeated input-reading logic.
The program can never sum or even see 5 different integers from the user.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely difficulty in translating "do this for 5 numbers" into a looping structure, or reliance on placeholder values without finishing the implementation loop.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for loop (e.g., for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++)) that, on each iteration, reads an integer, checks if it is even, and updates sum accordingly. Avoid hard-coding a single num value when the problem specifies multiple inputs.
related_concepts: Using loops to process a fixed number of inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The presence of sum and count plus a single num = 4 and no loop suggests an incomplete or misunderstood approach to handling multiple inputs.

evidence.note: Variables for an accumulation pattern exist, but only a single, hard-coded num is ever checked; there is no loop or repeated input reading to cover 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Problem Misidentification and Incorrect Input Handling
misconceptions.description: The student implemented logic and input reading for a completely different problem (calculating average acceleration using v0, v1, and t) instead of the requested task (summing 5 even integers). Additionally, the required 5 inputs were not read, and incorrect data types (doubles) were used.
misconceptions.student_belief: This task requires calculating average acceleration, or I confused this filename/slot with another assignment. The variables v0, v1, and t need to be read as input.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to solve Q1: Sum of Even Numbers, which requires reading five integer inputs and performing arithmetic on them. The acceleration formula is irrelevant.
symptoms: Program prints 'Enter v0, v1, and t:'
Program reads three doubles instead of five integers
Program calculates and prints 'The average acceleration is...'
misconceptions.root_cause: Major confusion between assignments or failure to replace template code tailored for another problem. Failed to address the core requirements of Q1.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Completely remove the code related to 'v0, v1, and t' and the acceleration calculation. Start by focusing on the core requirements: reading 5 integers using `input.nextInt()`.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code uses variable names (v0, v1, t) and output prompts/calculations explicitly referencing acceleration, which is outside the scope of the assigned problem.

evidence.note: The student is solving the average acceleration problem instead of the sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Failure to Use Iteration for Repetitive Input Processing
misconceptions.description: The student was required to process 5 inputs but failed to implement any loop structure (like a `for` or `while` loop). The summing logic only operates on a single hardcoded variable (`num = 4`) and is executed once.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can test the core logic on a single variable and meet the requirements, or perhaps iteration is optional if I demonstrate the accumulator logic.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To process a fixed number of multiple items (like 5 inputs), a `for` loop is typically required to iterate, read input, and apply the conditional logic repeatedly.
symptoms: No `for` or `while` loop is present
Input reading is not repeated 5 times
`num` is hardcoded to 4
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of understanding of how loops are used to handle multiple inputs specified in the problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Enclose your input reading and summing logic inside a `for` loop that iterates 5 times (i = 0 to 4). Inside the loop, read the input from the user.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The absence of any looping construct is absolute, and the use of 'int num = 4;' confirms a fixed value check rather than processing input iteratively.

evidence.note: The student initializes a single variable `num = 4` instead of reading multiple inputs inside a loop.

misconceptions.name: Missing Braces in Conditional Statements
misconceptions.description: The student uses multiple statements within the intended conditional block of the `if` statement but omits curly braces. In Java, only the first line (`sum += num;`) is executed conditionally, while the second line (`count++;`) executes unconditionally.
misconceptions.student_belief: Indentation is sufficient to define the scope of the `if` statement, causing both lines of code to execute only if the condition is true.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, if an `if` statement controls more than one line of code, those lines must be enclosed in curly braces `{}` to form a block. Without braces, only the immediately following statement is conditional.
symptoms: Statements intended for the conditional block are not enclosed in braces
misconceptions.root_cause: Syntactic confusion, possibly confusing Java's requirement with languages like Python where indentation determines scope.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always use curly braces { } around the body of `if` statements, especially when the body contains more than one line of code.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The structure clearly shows two statements indented after the `if` condition without braces, which is a common pattern for this specific syntactic error.

evidence.note: `count++;` is executed unconditionally because of the missing curly braces around the `if` block.

misconceptions.name: Solving wrong problem - reading physics variables instead of integers
misconceptions.description: The student appears to be solving a completely different problem (calculating acceleration) instead of reading 5 integers for the sum of even numbers task.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this assignment is asking them to calculate average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user input and computing the sum of only the even-valued numbers among those 5 integers.
symptoms: Program prompts for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of integers
Program reads and uses only 3 values instead of 5
Program calculates acceleration formula instead of summing even numbers
Output would show acceleration result, not sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may have copied code from a different assignment, misread the problem statement, or confused this assignment with another physics-related problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. The task is to read 5 integers and sum only the even ones. Start fresh with: (1) prompt for 5 integers, (2) use a loop to read all 5, (3) check each number with (num % 2 == 0), (4) accumulate only even numbers into sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code is solving a fundamentally different problem (acceleration calculation) with completely different variable names (v0, v1, t) and formula. This is clearly a case of wrong problem being solved, not a minor logic error.

evidence.note: This entire section is solving a physics problem (calculating acceleration) not the assigned problem (sum of even numbers). The prompt, variables, and calculation are all wrong for this assignment.

misconceptions.name: Missing loop to read 5 integers
misconceptions.description: The student has no loop structure to read multiple inputs. Only one hardcoded value (num = 4) is processed.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may believe that processing a single hardcoded number is sufficient, or that a loop is not necessary for handling multiple values.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To read and process 5 integers, a loop (such as a for loop) is essential. Without it, only one value can be processed at a time.
symptoms: No loop construct (for, while) in the code
Only one hardcoded integer (num = 4) is used
Cannot process 5 user inputs
Program will only check one value regardless of user input
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may not understand the necessity of loops for repetitive tasks, or may have focused on the wrong problem entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a for loop: for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { int num = input.nextInt(); ... } This will read exactly 5 integers from the user one at a time.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly lacks any loop structure and only hardcodes a single value. This is an obvious absence of required functionality.

evidence.note: The code initializes num to a hardcoded value (4) instead of reading from input in a loop. There is no loop structure to handle 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Missing output statement for the final sum
misconceptions.description: The program does not print the sum of even numbers at the end. The sum is calculated but never displayed to the user.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may believe that calculating a value is sufficient without explicitly printing it.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must print the final result. The required output format is: 'Sum of even numbers: [value]'
symptoms: No println or printf statement for the sum result
User will not see the computed sum
Program output will not match the expected sample output
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may have forgotten to include the output statement, or may be focused on the wrong problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a line like: System.out.printf("Sum of even numbers: %d\n", sum); at the end of the program.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly lacks any output statement for the sum. The problem explicitly requires printing the sum, and this is absent.

evidence.note: The sum is accumulated but there is no System.out.printf or System.out.println statement to display the result to the user.

misconceptions.name: Using hardcoded value instead of reading from user input
misconceptions.description: The student hardcodes num = 4 instead of reading values from the user via Scanner.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that a hardcoded test value is sufficient instead of actually reading from user input.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must read all 5 integers from the user using Scanner's nextInt() method within a loop.
symptoms: Single hardcoded value: int num = 4;
No use of input.nextInt() to read user values
Program ignores user input after the first three prompts
Cannot accept arbitrary integers from the user
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may have been writing test code with a hardcoded value and forgot to replace it with actual input reading, or may not understand how to use Scanner for multiple values.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace 'int num = 4;' with input.nextInt() calls inside a loop. For each iteration, read one integer and process it.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly shows int num = 4; with no input reading for the main task, despite having a Scanner object available.

evidence.note: Hardcoded value instead of reading from user input using input.nextInt().

misconceptions.name: Missing increment statement execution - conditional block scope error
misconceptions.description: The count++ statement is not inside the if block due to missing braces, so it will always execute regardless of whether the number is even or odd.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may not understand that without braces, only the first statement after an if is part of the conditional block.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, if a conditional statement has no braces, only the immediately following single statement is part of the if block. To include multiple statements, braces { } are required.
symptoms: count++ will execute regardless of the if condition
count will not accurately reflect the number of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may not be aware of Java's if statement scoping rules or may have forgotten braces.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add braces around both statements: if (num % 2 == 0) { sum += num; count++; }
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly shows indentation suggesting both statements should be in the if block, but only sum += num; is actually controlled by the if. This is a common syntactic mistake.

evidence.note: Missing braces around the if block. Only 'sum += num;' is controlled by the if condition. The 'count++;' statement will execute regardless.

misconceptions.name: Assuming indentation controls the scope of an if-statement without braces
misconceptions.description: The student appears to think that both `sum += num;` and `count++;` are controlled by the `if (num % 2 == 0)` condition because they are indented, even though only the first statement is actually part of the if-statement due to missing braces.
misconceptions.student_belief: If I write `if (condition)` and then indent multiple lines under it, all of those indented lines will only run when the condition is true, even if I don’t use braces.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, an `if` without braces controls exactly one statement—the very next one. To make multiple statements run conditionally, they must be grouped in braces `{ ... }`, e.g., `if (condition) { statement1; statement2; }`.
symptoms: `count++` will execute regardless of whether `num` is even or odd.
The visual indentation suggests both `sum += num;` and `count++;` are intended to be inside the if-block, but Java’s rules do not follow indentation.
If extended to multiple inputs, the count of even numbers would be incorrect.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion from languages or pseudocode where indentation defines blocks (like Python) or from reading code as if visual layout determined control flow rather than Java’s strict syntax rules about statement blocks.
misconceptions.remediation_hint:
Whenever you want more than one statement to be controlled by an `if`, always wrap those statements in `{}`. Rewrite this as:

```javaif (num % 2 == 0) {    sum += num;    count++;}```
Then test with both even and odd values to see that both lines only execute when the condition is true.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The indentation clearly groups `sum += num;` and `count++;` visually, but only one is syntactically under the `if`. This is a common beginner misconception and is consistent with the code pattern shown.

evidence.note: Because there are no braces, only `sum += num;` is controlled by the if-statement; `count++;` always executes. The indentation suggests the student believes both lines are inside the if-block.

misconceptions.name: Reading input for a different problem
misconceptions.description: The student reads inputs appropriate for a completely different problem (acceleration calculation: v0, v1, t as doubles) instead of the 5 integers required for the sum of even numbers task.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely copied input reading code from a previous exercise or template (like an acceleration calculation) and forgot to adapt it to read the 5 integers explicitly required for the current task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must be structured to read five distinct integer values from the standard input using `nextInt()` or equivalent methods, specifically for the 'Sum of Even Numbers' problem.
symptoms: Code asks for 'v0, v1, and t'
Uses `nextDouble()` instead of `nextInt()`
Only reads 3 inputs, not 5
Non-functional code for the assigned problem
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to switch context or properly review and modify boilerplate code when starting a new problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem description. You need to read exactly 5 integers. Replace the acceleration input code with a loop or five sequential input statements that read integers, not doubles.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The inputs read (v0, v1, t) and the prompt ('Enter v0, v1, and t:') are explicitly wrong for the problem 'Sum of Even Numbers'.

evidence.note: This block calculates acceleration, which is irrelevant. The required inputs (5 integers) are missing.

misconceptions.name: Lack of iterative processing (Looping)
misconceptions.description: The student does not use a loop structure (like `for` or `while`) to process the 5 required inputs iteratively, which is a fundamental requirement for handling multiple repetitive operations efficiently.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that reading 5 separate items may not require a loop, or they simply failed to implement the iterative structure needed to read and process 5 numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To efficiently read and process a fixed number of inputs (N=5), a loop (e.g., a `for` loop running 5 times) is necessary. Otherwise, the logic must be repeated 5 times manually.
symptoms: No `for` or `while` loop present to handle the 5 inputs
The logic for checking parity and summation is run only once on a hardcoded variable.
Rubric requirement for 'Loop structure' is failed.
misconceptions.root_cause: Incomplete implementation of the solution structure where sequential processing of multiple inputs is required.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Enclose the input reading, even check, and summation logic within a `for` loop that iterates exactly 5 times.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There is no loop structure present in the code; all operations are sequential or conditional on a single variable.

evidence.note: The core logic is applied only once to a hardcoded variable 'num', not iteratively to 5 user inputs.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoding input instead of processing user variable
misconceptions.description: The student initializes and uses a hardcoded integer variable (`int num = 4;`) for the core logic of checking for even numbers and summing, instead of using a variable that holds the user-provided input from `Scanner` within a loop.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student might believe that by defining `num=4`, they are testing a valid input case, but they failed to generalize this logic to process the actual user-provided data stream.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The variable used in the conditional check (`if (num % 2 == 0)`) must represent the input value read from the user during each iteration of the loop.
symptoms: The variable `num` is assigned `4` and never updated by user input.
The summation logic runs only once, calculating `sum = 4`.
User input (v0, v1, t) is read but never used for the intended calculation.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to connect the input mechanism (Scanner) with the processing logic (summation and conditional check).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Inside your loop structure, read the integer input and assign it to a variable (let's call it `num`). Then, use that variable in your `if` statement.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The assignment `int num = 4;` followed immediately by the conditional check confirms that the required input variable is being ignored for processing.

evidence.note: The variable 'num' is hardcoded to 4, preventing the program from using dynamic user input.

misconceptions.name: Improper Use of Conditional Block Braces
misconceptions.description: The student executes a subsequent statement (`count++`) unconditionally immediately following the `if` statement, indicating a misunderstanding of how single-statement `if` blocks work in Java when braces are omitted.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that indentation dictates control flow, and since `count++` is indented after the `if` block, it is executed only when the condition is true.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: In Java, an `if` statement without curly braces only controls the execution of the single statement immediately following it. All subsequent statements are executed normally, regardless of the condition.
symptoms: The `count++` statement is executed regardless of whether `num` is even.
Missing curly braces `{}` around the block of code meant to be executed conditionally.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion between Java's syntax rules (single statement following `if` vs. block of statements) and indentation-based languages (like Python).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always use curly braces `{}` when you want more than one statement to be controlled by an `if` condition. Even for single statements, braces are recommended for clarity and preventing this exact error.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The indentation strongly suggests the student intended both `sum += num;` and `count++;` to be conditional, but only the first statement is. This is a common error stemming from language confusion.

evidence.note: Line 17 (`count++`) executes unconditionally because braces are missing.

misconceptions.name: Using hardcoded values instead of reading from input
misconceptions.description: The student assigns a fixed constant (num = 4) instead of reading values from the keyboard using Scanner. This suggests a misunderstanding that data for a program should come from user input rather than being predetermined in code.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the value to be checked can be hardcoded directly in the program (e.g., 'int num = 4;') rather than being read from user input.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When a program is intended to work with user-provided data, values must be read from input using Scanner methods (nextInt(), nextDouble(), etc.). The program should not assume what the input values will be.
symptoms: Program uses 'int num = 4;' instead of reading input
Program does not prompt for or accept 5 user integers as required
Program will always check the same value regardless of what the user enters
misconceptions.root_cause: Possible confusion between hardcoded test values (used during development) and the final program that must accept user input. The student may not understand that each run of the program should process different user-provided data.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use a loop with Scanner.nextInt() to read 5 integers from the user. For example: 'for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { int num = input.nextInt(); ... }'
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the code explicitly contains 'int num = 4;' and never uses Scanner.nextInt() to read the 5 integers. This is a clear deviation from the problem requirements.

evidence.note: Instead of reading 5 integers from input, the student hardcodes a single value.
Only one hardcoded number is checked; no loop to process 5 integers from input.

misconceptions.name: Failure to use loop for repeated operations
misconceptions.description: The student does not implement any loop structure to process the 5 integers. Instead, a single hardcoded value is checked once. This reflects a misconception that repetitive operations (reading and checking 5 numbers) require iteration.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that processing multiple data items (5 integers) can be done without a loop, perhaps checking only one example value is sufficient.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When the same operation must be performed on multiple pieces of data, a loop structure (for, while, do-while) is essential. To process 5 integers, the code must iterate 5 times, reading and checking each one.
symptoms: No for or while loop in the code
Only one integer is processed (hardcoded num = 4)
Program does not adapt to different numbers of inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: The student may not have learned loop structures yet, or may not recognize when a loop is needed. This could stem from solving the problem manually (checking 5 numbers on paper) without translating that repetition into code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a for loop: 'for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++)' and move the integer reading and even-check logic inside the loop block.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Critical misconception is evident: the code has no loop structure whatsoever, yet the problem explicitly requires processing 5 integers. This is unambiguous.

evidence.note: Main method contains no loop; the if statement only executes once on hardcoded value.
